radiographic_examinations.findings: Decreased attenuation bilaterally throughout the cerebellum and smaller focal areas in the occipital, temporal, and subcortical areas of white matter, with mass effect in the fourth ventricle and signs of early hydrocephalus.
Extensive infarction in the posterior fossa with sparing of the brainstem, and herniation of the cerebellar contents and compression of the brainstem.
Normal caliper carotid and vertebral arteries, with a dominant left vertebral artery, but no evidence of arterial dissection, arterial injury, or anomaly.

No evidence of fracture or subluxation, with the vertebral heights and disk spaces maintained, but a questionable calcific density noted superior to the posterior arch of C1 indicating the possibility of an arcuate foramen.
